data.title: Unhappy prompt to install extension after just installing it
data.body: - run `ext install` - find an extension and press the little install button and see how it shows progress - press the readme-button which takes you the website - :boom: returning to VS Code prompts me to (1) restart after installing X and (2) also if I want to install X

data.title: OmniSharp no longer works on Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders candidate
- OS Version: Ubuntu 15.10

>= Mono v4.0.1 seems to be required now

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/13928428/c8070e08-ef52-11e5-95cf-b600f0233958.png)

It points me to [this page](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/supporting/errors#_20001) which advises:

> Error: Cannot start OmniSharp because Mono version >=3.10.0 is required.

As well as this (another version??):

> Currently, debugging support of VS Code on Linux or OS X requires Mono version 3.12 or later.

And says install via `sudo apt-get install mono-complete`. The latest mono-complete registered in the default Ubuntu repository seems to be 3.2.8:

```
â¯ mono --version
Mono JIT compiler version 3.2.8 (Debian 3.2.8+dfsg-4ubuntu4)
Copyright (C) 2002-2014 Novell, Inc, Xamarin Inc and Contributors. www.mono-project.com
    TLS:           __thread
    SIGSEGV:       altstack
    Notifications: epoll
    Architecture:  amd64
    Disabled:      none
    Misc:          softdebug 
    LLVM:          supported, not enabled.
    GC:            sgen
```

data.title: Selecting install extension then clicking Readme shows two conflicting dialogs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. F1 -> Install extension
2. Click install button
3. Click Readme button
4. Click out of the command window

Actual:
Two notifications come up. One asking if you would like to install that extension (which you already have) and another that says you need to restart to enable the extension.

![installreadme](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/13928224/154649a0-ef52-11e5-97a2-9b4a4ffc60e8.JPG)

Expected:
Only the "restart to enable it." dialog to show up.

data.title: Remove watch expression X icon is misaligned

data.title: Provide an option to not mix symbols and files in quick open
data.body:
When pressing `ctrl+p` to open the quick open panel and typing a few letters to look for a file, the panel seems to show symbols matching my string first, then some files. Worse, it mixes files & symbols.

![quickopen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/13927121/a67e3274-ef8f-11e5-9f79-9960e656c953.png)

It makes it really difficult to quickly open a filename: I really need to be carreful when typing
And it seems to return too many matches too.

For example, typing `stenci` would return '**S**I**T**UATION_**E**CRA**N**_**C**LIENT' which is not even closer to "stencil".

I guess this kind of match should only work with captial letters found into camel case words, not in full uppercase.

What about having an option to only display files in Ctrl+P panel ? Isn't the Symbol panel there for showing symbols ?
- VSCode Version:0.10.12 insider
- OS Version: Win 10

See attached gif, the progress bar quickly goes to ~90% and then takes a long while until it reaches 100%.

data.title: (Discussion) Possible to launch multiple debuggers?
data.body:
I'm interested in understanding what it would take to be able to run multiple debuggers at once in the same vscode instance.

For example, simultaneously debugging a rails app's ruby code (eg, with the [recently featured](http://code.visualstudio.com/blogs/2016/03/11/ExtensionsRoundup) [ruby debugger](https://github.com/rebornix/vscode-ruby)) and its javascript code (eg, with [vs-chrome-debug](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-chrome-debug)). I'm envisioning breakpoints in both server and client code, with the respective debugger handling the respective file types.

How feasible is this? What kind of undertaking would it be to be able to activate more than one launch.json configuration entry at once?

data.title: Different font in different regions
data.body: It would be nice if you could select i.e. a different font for comments in comparison to code just for better reading. It's not a pressing matter but nice to have :)

data.title: Bugfix: Prevent overwrite of modeAtPosition
data.body:
In _delegateToModePosition the modeAtPosition would be overwritten and then the callback function would call the wrong thing in the getRangeAtPosition.
Sadly this does not fix the issue with getting no range in the smartSelect because still there is no range returned. But this might be a step in the right direction I hope.

data.title: Allow keybindings.json on .vscode folder.
data.body:
If I want to share some shortcuts in my project repository I can't configure them inside `.vscode` and commit to my team.
It would be nice to have the same behavior as `.vscode/settings.json`

data.title: remove IExecutionService and base/hash.ts
data.body: All of that seems to be unused code.

data.title: red in default light theme too subtle
data.body: Like quite a few other men (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_blindness#Frequency_of_red-green_color_blindness_in_males_of_various_populations) I suffer from impaired red/green vision and for my eyes the red value `rgba(128, 0, 0, 1)` from our default light theme is almost impossible to tell apart from the default black.

data.title: Unable to fork a node process from extension server
[html][angular] Provide string based autocompletion when writing angular directives in html

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In an angular based app, define a controller in a controllers.js file
2. In an html page, add the ng-controller directive to an html element. When specifying the name of the controller (a string), it would be very useful to have smart string based autocompletion, where strings defined in other files can be used to fill in the name. Atom does this and it's very helpful to make sure that you don't get the name of the controller, or other angular components wrong.

data.title: Open the automatically created jsconfig.json file in a new editor, if one is available
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create an ionic starter app with 'ionic start myIonicApp blank'
2. Open a js file
3. Click on the lightbulb in the status bar, then click the 'Create jsconfig.json' button in the prompt

Expected: The newly created jsconfig.json file opens up in a new editor and does not interfere with any of the currently open editors.
Actual: The new jsconfig.json file opens up in the editor that I currently have open, replacing the file that I had previously opened.

If all three editors are already open, open the file in the active editor (as current behaviour).

data.title: Provide comments in jsconfig.json to guide people towards using tsd to install typings file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create an ionic starter app with 'ionic start myIonicApp blank'
2. Open a js file
3. Click on the lightbulb in the status bar, then click the 'Create jsconfig.json' button in the prompt

Expected: A comment in the jsconfig.json file that describes how to use tsd to add typings file to the project in order to get the rich intellisense that was described in the prompt on step 3.

data.title: Feature request : add in code 'debugger;' to breakpoints panel for .ts and .js files

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hello,

Typescript and javascript support `debugger;` to stop the debugging process when hitting.

It would be great to show those breakpoints in the breakpoints panel for info and even add a checkbox to show/hide such a feature.

Thank you in advance for your feedback.
